questions.question: Which of the following neurotransmitter is not a biogenic amine?
The main excitatory and inhibitory neurotransmitters in the CNS are

options.B: Aspartate and glycine respectivelyNorepinephrine and GABA respectivelyd) Dopamine and GABA respectivelyQuestion 3:'A' delta fibers and 'C' fibers carry pain sensation. The neurotransmitter released by 'A' deltafibers isa) Substance Pb) Glutamate

questions.explanation: Glutamate is the main excitatory neurotransmitter in the CNS. It is responsible for 75% of theexcitatory transmission in the brain.Glycine and GABA are the main inhibitory neurotransmitters in the CNS. Glycine is the maininhibitory neurotransmitter in the spinal cord. GABA is the major inhibitory neurotransmitter inthe brain.

questions.question: The most important neurotransmitter of reward pathway is
questions.explanation: The most important neurotransmitter of reward pathway is dopamine.203Reward pathway (mesolimbic pathway) connects the ventral tegmental area in the midbrain to thenucleus accumbens and limbic subcortical areas. This pathway is involved in reward behaviour,addiction and in psychiatric disorders such as schizophrenia.

questions.question: Dopamine beta hydroxylase converts dopamine to
questions.explanation: Dopamine beta hydroxylase converts dopamine to norepinephrine. Vitamin C is required as acofactor for the enzyme.Catecholamine synthesisTyrosineTyrosinehydroxylaseDihydroxyphenylalanine(DOPA)Amino aciddecarboxylaseDopamineDopamine-ẞ-hydroxylaseWNorepinephrinePhenylethanolamine-N-methyltransferaseEpinephrineOMARROW

questions.question: Which of these is not a dopaminergic pathway?
questions.explanation: Corticostrial pathway is not a dopaminergic pathway.The corticostrial pathway is the primary input pathway for the basal ganglia which uses glutamateas the neurotransmitter.Important dopaminergic pathways are:• Mesolimbic pathway - Increased activity responsible for positive symptoms of schizophrenia.• Mesocortical pathway - Decreased activity responsible for negative symptoms of schizophrenia.• Nigrostriatal pathway - Decreased activity causes extrapyramidal symptoms.•Tuberoinfundibular pathway - Decreased activity causes increase in prolactin.204MesocorticalpathwayNigrostriatalpathwayTubero-infundibularpathwayPituitaryMesolimbicpathwaySpinal cordDorsal StriatumThalamusNucleusaccumbensHypothalamusCerebellumSubstantiaNigraVentralTegmental Area

questions.question: Find the incorrect match.
questions.explanation: Basal forebrain complex (nucleus basalis of Meynert) is rich in acetylcholine.A loss of cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert is seen in alzheimer's disease.

questions.question: A patient with involuntary jerking and writhing movements is diagnosed with Huntington'sdisease. Loss of which of the following is responsible for hyperkinetic symptoms in thiscondition?
questions.explanation: The hyperkinetic feature of Huntington's disease is due to the loss of intrastriatal GABAergic andcholinergic neurons. The loss of the GABAergic pathway (which is an inhibitory pathway) to theglobus pallidus external segment and loss of cholinergic neurons in many parts of the braindecreases inhibition, causing the hyperkinetic feature of the disease to develop.Huntington's disease is an autosomal dominant trinucleotide repeat disorder with multiple CAGrepeats. The abnormal gene responsible for the disease is located on chromosome 4.

questions.question: An infant develops features of botulism following honey intake. This toxin blocksneuromuscular transmission by which of the following mechanisms?

options.A: Prevents release of Ach at presynaptic membrane
options.B: Opening of calcium channels at the presynaptic membrane
options.C: Prevents the binding of Ach at the postsynatic membrane
options.D: Prevents the action of Ach at the postsynaptic membrane

questions.explanation: Botulinum toxin prevents the release of Ach at the presynaptic membrane.Botulinum toxins A, B, and E are toxic to humans. They cleave components of SNARE - a complexof proteins necessary for the exocytosis of acetylcholine. Toxins A and E cleave SNAP-25 whereastoxin B cleaves vesicle-associated membrane protein (VAMP) also known as synaptobrevin.Cleavage of SNARE proteins prevents the release of acetylcholine as the vesicles containing Achare unable to bind to the presynaptic membrane.205

questions.question: A farmer presents with difficulty swallowing and jaw tightening. He gives a history of gettinghis finger jammed in the rustic gate a few days ago. He gives no history of previous tetanusimmunization. After evaluation, he was diagnosed with tetanus. The release of which of thefollowing neurotransmitters is affected by the toxin responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation: Tetanus toxin affects the release of GABA.Tetanus toxin escapes normal lysosomal degradation and crosses the synapse to the GABA-ergicpresynaptic inhibitory interneuron terminals. The toxin blocks the release of inhibitoryneurotransmitters (glycine and gamma-aminobutyric acid) across the synaptic cleft. This blockageof the inhibitory neurotransmitters causes spastic paralysis.

questions.question: The neurotransmitter released by Renshaw cell interneuron is
questions.explanation: The neurotransmitter released by Renshaw cell interneuron is glycine.Renshaw cell is an inhibitory interneuron which is activated by collaterals from spinal motorneurons. Renshaw cell terminates on the cell body of the same and other spinal motor neurons. Itreduces or stops the discharge of the motor neuron by releasing glycine.Renshaw cell inhibitionRRInhibitoryinterneuron(RENSHAW CELL)OMARROWMotor neuron-Axon

questions.question: 200Which of the following neurotransmitters is increased during REM sleep?
questions.explanation: Acetylcholine increases during REM sleep.In REM sleep, there is increase in acetylcholine and decrease in norepinephrine and serotonin.The reverse of this pattern leads to wakefulness.Neurotransmitters in REM slLevels of neurotransmitteeeprAcetylcholineSerotoninNorepinephrineIncreasedDecreasedDecreased206

questions.question: Which of the following is the wrong match?

options.C: Sympathetic post ganglionic fibres release noradrenaline
options.D: Sweat glands - innervated by sympathetic adrenergic fibres

questions.explanation: Sweat glands are innervated by sympathetic cholinergic fibres (not adrenergic fibres).Pre-ganglionic fibres of the sympathetic nervous system, pre-ganglionic fibers of theparasympathetic nervous system and post-ganglionic parasympathetic fibres release acetylcholine.Post-ganglionic sympathetic fibres release noradrenaline in most of the sites, except in certainplaces such as sweat glands, piloerector muscles and blood vessels in some skeletal muscles whereacetylcholine is released.

questions.question: Which part of the basal ganglia is the neurotransmitter glutamate secreted from?
questions.explanation: Projections from subthalamic nucleus to globus pallidus are glutaminergic.Neurotransmitters secreted by various regions of basal ganglia:• Substantia nigra pars compacta = dopamine• Substantia nigra pars reticulata= GABA•Subthalmic nuclei = glutamate•• Corpus striatum to globus pallidus = GABA.• Intrastriate neurons =acetylcholine• Globus pallidus = GABABasal gangliaStriatumGABAGABAGABAGlobus pallidusGlobus pallidusinternaexternaSubstantia nigraPars reticulataGlutamateGABASubthalamicnucleusOMARROWDopamineSubstantia nigraPars compactaDiagrammatic representation of the principal connections of the basal ganglia.Acetylcholine is the transmitter produced by interneurons in the striatum.207(SNr substantia nigra pars reticulata; SNc: substantia nigra pars compacta; STN: Subthalamicnucleus; GPe: globus pallidus externa ; GPi: Globus pallidus interna).

questions.question: All of the following are excitatory neurotransmitters except:
questions.explanation: Serotonin is an inhibitory neurotransmitter.Acetylcholine, glutamate and norepinephrine are excitatory neurotransmitters.

questions.question: Which of the following is not true about serotonin receptor?201
questions.explanation: 5-HT2C receptor agonists increase satiety (state of being fed beyond capacity).Important serotonin receptors:• 5-HT2A receptors mediate platelet aggregation and smooth muscle contraction.• 5-HT3 receptors are present in the GIT and the area postrema and are related to vomiting.• 5-HT4 receptors are present in the GIT and brain. They facilitate secretion and peristalsis inGIT.• 5-HT6 and 5-HT7 are distributed throughout the limbic system.Note: All are G protein coupled receptors except 5-HT3 which is a ligand gated ion channelreceptor.

questions.question: Serotonin is present in highest concentration in
questions.explanation: Serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine; 5-HT) is present in highest concentration in platelets and in thegastrointestinal tract, where it is found in the enterochromaffin cells and the myenteric plexus. Itis also found within the brain stem in the midline Raphe nuclei.Note: The precursor of serotonin is tryptophan.208Serotonin metabolismTryptophanTryptophanHydroxylase5-Hydroxytryptophan (5HTP)L Amino aciddecarboxylaseROWSerotonin(5HT-Hydroxytryptamine)MAO(Monoamineoxidase)5-Hydroxy indoleacetic acid (5HIAA)MAMARROW

questions.question: Which statement regarding the NMDA receptor is incorrect?

options.B: Glycine is essential for this receptor's response to its endogenous agonist
options.C: It is a chloride ion channel
options.D: It is present in hippocampal neurons

questions.explanation: NMDA receptor permits passage of Ca2+ and other cations (Na+), not of chloride.Glutamate is the agonist for NMDA receptor. Glycine binding to the NMDA receptor is essentialfor the receptor to respond to glutamate. NMDA receptors are present on hippocampal neurons.Note: GABA and glycine receptors act by increasing Cl- conductance.209
